in the United States were in the middle
of an election season and as a voter in

candidates to at two to actually

acknowledge and provide proposals that
are realistic about how they are going

to take care of workers and the middle
class in the midst of these massive

economic transformations that are aided

we're witnessing all around us I would
ask our candidates again in the United

States election to explain to us how
they are going to maintain economic

security in a country that give becomes

sufficient to overcome these
inequalities that I'm writing about and

Beyond the Valley but they are really

of the most powerful aspects of the

places I went to university at both my

undergrad and graduate degrees offer
free online and open courses completely

free taught by professors at Stanford at
MIT you know and doesn't have to just be

those universities it could be almost
anywhere right so I would really

technological literacy artificial

possibilities and actually human

but part two is be really as much as

different kinds of platforms right so

like what have you look used DuckDuckGo
instead of Google how would the results

be different what have you deleted just
play what have you deleted like your

cache in your search history would that
impact anything on Google develop a

literacy through playfulness try to
understand in a more relational or

experiential sense what digital pathways
might look like that's a second point

the third I would say is there are a
number of good books and writers and

talks and TED Talks etc I hope I'm one
of them with my book beyond the valley

but there are a number of others who are
writing for a completely mainstream

public about these digital
transformations and I would really

encourage everybody to look at some of

some as well Cathy O'Neil she's pretty
incredible she wrote a book called

weapons of mass destruction it's a
really cute title and it's just a really

really good book and it's an important
book but there are other books as well

that we can consider and last and I
think very importantly is to look at the

right journalistic sources that are also
reporting on these issues

ProPublica has done great work on this
the intercept has done some work on this

The Guardian has done some work on this
there are a lot of different kinds of

platforms wired of course has done great

making labor and work obsolete in the

for whom is really the question we have

to ask them for all the jobs for all

to provide us with something - and here
are all these different possibilities we

can engage with from you know thinking
about universal basic income ideas to

ideas there's a lot out there and I ask

optimism but push you know we got to
push on all fronts we are at an

inflection point when it comes to
top-down

control over very many different aspects
of our lives through privatized

corporate power over technology we can
work with these guys and try to push

balance in our lives
